required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Spinal Manipulative Therapy Treatment Effect Modifiers in Individuals With Low Back Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Spinal Manipulative Therapy Treatment Effect Modifiers in Individuals With Low Back Pain

brief_summary.textblock: This study considers whether treatment effects in response to spinal manipulative therapy for individuals experiencing low back pain are dependent upon the context in which the intervention is provided. Half of the participants will receive spinal manipulative therapy with encouragement to interact with the provider and information to enhance expectations for the effectiveness of the intervention. The other half will receive spinal manipulative therapy with minimal interaction with the provider.

primary_outcome.description: 0 to 100 with 0= no pain at all to 100= worst pain imaginable

secondary_outcome.description: 0 to 100 with 0= no perceived disability to 100= greatest perceived disability

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in baseline immediately following spinal manipulative therapy during day 1 and at 2 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: 0 to 15 with lower scores indicating better performance

secondary_outcome.time_frame: change in baseline immediately following spinal manipulative therapy during day 1
secondary_outcome.description: standardized thermal and pressure stimuli will be applied and participant will rate the pain associated with each using a 0= no pain to 100= worst pain imaginable numeric pain rating scale or a mechanical visual analog scale anchored with no pain and worst pain imaginable

secondary_outcome.time_frame: change in baseline immediately following spinal manipulative therapy during day 1
secondary_outcome.description: Participants indicate their usual level, desired level, successful level, and expected level of pain, fatigue, emotional distress, and interference using a 0= none at all to 100= worst imaginable numeric rating scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Working alliance subscale of the Pain Rehabilitation Expectation Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: change in baseline immediately following spinal manipulative therapy during day 1
secondary_outcome.description: Scored from 16= lesser therapeutic alliance to 64= greater therapeutic alliance

secondary_outcome.measure: North American Spine Society Lumbar Spine Outcome Assessment
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will answer 3 questions: 1) If you had to spend the rest of your life with the low back pain you have right now, how would you feel about it? Scored from 1= very dissatisfied to 5= very satisfied; 2) Would you have the same intervention you received in this study again for low back pain? Scored from 1=Definitely not to 5= definitely yes; 3) . How would you rate the overall results of the intervention you received in this study for low back pain? Scored from 1= Terrible to 6= Excellent

arm_group.description: Participants in this group will receive spinal manipulative therapy provided by a practitioner interacting in a warm and friendly way who is free to respond to participant conversation. Participants in this group will receive information about the effectiveness of spinal manipulative therapy for some individuals experiencing low back pain.

Participants in this group will receive spinal manipulative therapy provided by a practitioner engaging in minimal interaction. Participants in this group will not receive information about the effectiveness of spinal manipulative therapy for some individuals experiencing low back pain.
